Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Laboratory Experiment to Quantify the Impact of Whitecap Foam on Air-Sea Momentum Transfer
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is motivated by the need to improve parameterization of air-to-sea momentum fluxes. This research is expected to result in an in-depth understanding of the impact whitecap foam has on momentum transfer at the air-sea interface. The impact of whitecap foam on air-sea momentum flux will be studied in the laboratory environment using the Air-Sea Interaction Saltwater Tank (ASIST) at the University of Miami. The results will lead to improved parameterization of the momentum transfer at the air-sea interface which is important for ocean and climate modeling, hurricane forecasting, and modeling waves which effect coastal erosion and offshore energy.

This project will quantify the impact of whitecap foam on air-sea momentum transfer using the Air-Sea Interaction Saltwater Tank (ASIST) at the University of Miami. Foam will be generated by purging air through gas permeable tubing to imitate residual foam which lingers on the surface after a wave has broken. Wind will then be blown over the foam patch and turbulent momentum flux measured at two locations downwind for comparison to clean, foam-free water. The experiment will be conducted using a range of wind speeds and foam areas. Both fresh water and natural sea water will be used and bubble size and stability will be adjusted by altering surfactant concentrations. The outcome of this research will be a quantification of the impact whitecap foam has on air-sea momentum transfer by altering the surface roughness over a variety of conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accurate weather and climate prediction is intimately tied to our understanding of wind-wave interactions. A pivotal element of this interaction is the momentum transfer occurring at the air-sea boundary which causes waves to grow until they reach some critical steepness and break. During this phase, whitecaps initially manifest as active formations (Stage A) and subsequently as residuals (Stage B). This lingering residual foam, with its lifespan in tens of seconds, modifies the physics and chemistry of the air-sea boundary layer. However, the influence of whitecap foam on surface roughness and its effect on the growth of subsequent waves remains unknown. To remedy this, we conducted a laboratory experiment at the University of Miami's Air-Sea Interaction Saltwater Tank. Here, wind was blown over artificially generated Stage B whitecap foam, and we recorded the momentum flux and wave elevation downwind, contrasting it to foam-free cases. Our results show that foam can suppress the momentum transfer at the air-sea interface and reduce the wave height. Furthermore, the foam can increase the contribution of the wave form stress to the total stress. Improved understanding of air-sea interaction resulting from this experiment is expected to guide more accurate momentum flux and wave growth parameterization, leading to advances in weather and climate model accuracy.
